verses.verse: The plans of the mind belong to mortals, but the answer of the tongue is from the LORD.
(Prov 21.2) All one’s ways may be pure in one’s own eyes, but the LORD weighs the spirit.
(Ps 37.5) Commit your work to the LORD, and your plans will be established.
(Job 21.30; Isa 43.7) The LORD has made everything for its purpose, even the wicked for the day of trouble.
(Prov 6.17; 11.21) All those who are arrogant are an abomination to the LORD; be assured, they will not go unpunished.
(Prov 14.16; Dan 4.27) By loyalty and faithfulness iniquity is atoned for, and by the fear of the LORD one avoids evil.
(2 Chr 17.10) When the ways of people please the LORD, he causes even their enemies to be at peace with them.
Better is a little with righteousness than large income with injustice.
(Ps 37.23; Prov 20.24; Jer 10.23) The human mind plans the way, but the LORD directs the steps.
Inspired decisions are on the lips of a king; his mouth does not sin in judgment.
(Prov 11.1) Honest balances and scales are the LORD’s; all the weights in the bag are his work.
(Prov 25.5) It is an abomination to kings to do evil, for the throne is established by righteousness.
(Prov 14.35) Righteous lips are the delight of a king, and he loves those who speak what is right.
(Prov 19.12) A king’s wrath is a messenger of death, and whoever is wise will appease it.
(Job 29.23) In the light of a king’s face there is life, and his favor is like the clouds that bring the spring rain.
(Prov 8.10, 19) How much better to get wisdom than gold! To get understanding is to be chosen rather than silver.
The highway of the upright avoids evil; those who guard their way preserve their lives.
(Prov 11.2) Pride goes before destruction and a haughty spirit before a fall.
It is better to be of a lowly spirit among the poor than to divide the spoil with the proud.
(Ps 2.12; 34.8; Jer 17.7) Those who are attentive to a matter will prosper, and happy are those who trust in the LORD.
The wise of heart is called perceptive, and pleasant speech increases persuasiveness.
(Prov 7.22; 13.14) Wisdom is a fountain of life to one who has it, but folly is the punishment of fools.
The mind of the wise makes their speech judicious and adds persuasiveness to their lips.
Pleasant words are like a honeycomb, sweetness to the soul and health to the body.
(Prov 14.12) Sometimes there is a way that seems to be right, but in the end it is the way to death.
The appetite of workers works for them; their hunger urges them on.
(Prov 6.12, 14, 18; Jas 3.6) Scoundrels concoct evil, and their speech is like a scorching fire.
(Prov 15.18; 17.9) A perverse person spreads strife, and a whisperer separates close friends.
(Prov 1.10) The violent entice their neighbors and lead them in a way that is not good.
One who winks the eyes plans (Gk Syr Vg Tg: Heb to plan) perverse things; one who compresses the lips brings evil to pass.
(Prov 20.29) Gray hair is a crown of glory; it is gained in a righteous life.
(Prov 19.11) One who is slow to anger is better than the mighty, and one whose temper is controlled than one who captures a city.
The lot is cast into the lap, but the decision is the LORD’s alone.
